text:
After going through the emails I see a couple of things that are contradictory:
* Rich Schenk said: “Appears the PCB manufacturer has masking all
the way to the thru-hole part”
* Vitaly Michalchuk said : "I’ve been bouncing this around here on our end and what we’re thinking is you should try a more aggressive flux. With OSP, it’s really common that once the board goes through reflow, the ops burns off and the pads start contaminating.”
* OSP refers to organic solderability preservatives. It's a transparent film on top of the copper to prevent oxidation which makes it easy to solder to. Solder wont bond to oxidation 
* A strong flux will work well but we will need to clean the flux off afterwards with a flux remover. Otherwise the flux could eat away other stuff that could lead to a latent failure.
boards were sent via USPS (ugh) to Intel. Trying to source them and see if we can get a courier to pick them up.
fun
im going to walk over to the electronics store and get the supplies we need to neutralize and clean off the flux

attachments.title: Comparing Low-Power Wireless Technologies | DigiKey
attachments.text: An in-depth comparison of features, advantages, and benefits of using various types of low-power wireless technologies in a variety of applications.

text: 5 years old now, but good fundamentals on wireless power profiles
<http://www.ti.com/lsds/ti/wireless_connectivity/sub-1_ghz/simplelink-ulp-sub-1-ghz.page>

attachments.title: Sub-1 GHz | SimpleLink Ultra-low Power Platform | Wireless Connectivity | Products | TI.com
attachments.text: Sub-1 GHz technology utilizes less crowded, lower frequency bands (169 MHZ, 315 MHz, 433 MHz, 470 MHz, 868 MHz, 915 MHz and 920 MHz ISM Band), allowing you to communicate further distances and operate at lower power. The CC1310 is the lowest power and the most integrated solution, with the longest range.
